com.camerontec.util.logger.hpl.io

Class TailingHighPerformanceLogPlayer

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.camerontec.util.logger.hpl.io.TailingHighPerformanceLogPlayer
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    HighPerformanceLogPlayer, Callable<Void>

    public final class TailingHighPerformanceLogPlayer
extends Object
implements Callable<Void>, HighPerformanceLogPlayer
    Class capable of playing and tailing HighPerformanceLogEvents from a high performance logger directory.

    This class may also be run as a standalone application.

    Programmatic consumers have access to the timestamp and offset information contained in each HighPerformanceLogEvent that is played. That is, programmatic consumers are expected to be able to keep track of where they're up to and be able to supply the timestamp and file offset of the last event received in order to resume a discontinued playback session.

    Nonetheless, event listeners must be able to handle duplicate events as it is always possible to stream from the start.

    Events are played continuously until stop() is called, including events that arrive after the player is started. That is, the player has the effect of continuously tailing the high performance logs.

    • Constructor Detail

      • TailingHighPerformanceLogPlayer

        public TailingHighPerformanceLogPlayer(File directoryHandle,
                                       long timestamp,
                                       IHighPerformanceLogPlayerListener listener)
        Constructor.

        High performance log events from the specified high performance log directory and starting position will be played back.

        At the time of construction the following preconditions must be true otherwise an exception is thrown:

        • The log directory must exist and be readable
        • There must be at least one log file present in the specified log directory (i.e. we do not await log file creation), however, it may be empty.

        This constructor variant allows log playing to commence from an event specified only by timestamp. The rules governing this are:

        • If timestamp is ≤ 0L then log playback commences at the first available log event
        • If timestamp is > 0L then log playback commences at the first available log event with a timestamp ≥ to timestamp. If no such log events are currently available then we await future events to be written.
        Parameters:
        directoryHandle - The high performance log directory. Must not be null, must exist and must be a directory.
        timestamp - The timestamp of the log file entry prior to the required starting entry. Both timestamp and offset are ignored unless timestamp is positive and logs are played from the start of the first available log file. Note also that the timestamp may not be in the future as that open the possibility of selectively skipping log events which have not yet occurred and that is not supported.
        listener - The listener via which high performance log events are played back. Must not be null.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - If any parameter is null.
        IllegalArgumentException - If the specified directory is invalid or if no starting file corresponding to the specified timestamp and offset can be found.

      • TailingHighPerformanceLogPlayer

        public TailingHighPerformanceLogPlayer(File directoryHandle,
                                       long timestamp,
                                       long offset,
                                       IHighPerformanceLogPlayerListener listener)
        Constructor.

        High performance log events from the specified high performance log directory and starting position will be played back.

        At the time of construction the following preconditions must be true otherwise an exception is thrown:

        • The log directory must exist and be readable
        • There must be at least one log file present in the specified log directory (i.e. we do not await log file creation), however, it may be empty.
        Parameters:
        directoryHandle - The high performance log directory. Must not be null, must exist and must be a directory.
        timestamp - The timestamp of the log file entry prior to the required starting entry. Both timestamp and offset are ignored unless timestamp is positive and logs are played from the start of the first available log file. Note also that the timestamp may not be in the future as that open the possibility of selectively skipping log events which have not yet occurred and that is not supported.
        offset - The offset in the log file of the entry prior to the required starting entry. If the specificed offset is < 0L then it is not considered when determining the first event to be played back. That is, only the timestamp is used. If the offset is ≥ 0 then it is considered when determining the first event to be played back and in that case there must be a log event exactly matching timestamp and offset otherwise an exception is thrown.
        listener - The listener via which high performance log events are played back. Must not be null.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - If any parameter is null.
        IllegalArgumentException - If the specified directory is invalid or if no starting file corresponding to the specified timestamp and offset can be found.

      • TailingHighPerformanceLogPlayer

        public TailingHighPerformanceLogPlayer(File directoryHandle,
                                       int tailFromNthEvent,
                                       IHighPerformanceLogPlayerListener listener)
        Constructor.

        High performance log events from the specified high performance log directory will be played back starting from the specified nth event from the end, including any events which are subsequently appended to the log.

        At the time of construction the following preconditions must be true otherwise an exception is thrown:

        • The log directory must exist and be readable
        • There must be at least one log file present in the specified log directory (i.e. we do not await log file creation), however, it may be empty.
        Parameters:
        directoryHandle - The high performance log directory. Must not be null, must exist and must be a directory.
        tailFromNthEvent - The number of events from the end from which to start playback.
        listener - The listener via which high performance log events are played back. Must not be null.
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - If any parameter is null.
        IllegalArgumentException - If the specified directory is invalid or if no starting file corresponding to the specified parameters can be found.

    • Method Detail

      • main

        @Deprecated
public static void main(String[] args)
        Deprecated. Use ViewLogs.main(java.lang.String[]).
        Main entry point.

        Usages:

        1. TailingHighPerformanceLoggerPlayer - plays then tails all log events from the current directory
        2. TailingHighPerformanceLoggerPlayer [directory] - plays then tails all log events from the specified directory
        3. TailingHighPerformanceLoggerPlayer [directory] [timestamp] [offset] - plays then tails log events from the specified directory after the event with the specified timestamp and file offset.

        When run as a standalone application it continues polling for new events forever. The process must be killed for it to stop.

        Parameters:
        args - The program arguments.

      • start

        public void start()
        Play all log events from the event immediately following the one at the specified starting position.

        Note that programmatic consumers have access to the timestamp and offset information contained in each HighPerformanceLogEvent that is played. That is, programmatic consumers are expected to be able to keep track of where they're up to.

        Events are played continuously until stop() is called, including events that arrive after the player is started. That is, the player has the effect of continuously tailing the high performance logs.

        Specified by:
        start in interface HighPerformanceLogPlayer
        See Also:
        HighPerformanceLogEvent.getTimestamp(), HighPerformanceLogEvent.getFilePosition()

      • start

        public void start(CyclicBarrier barrier)
        This method is exactly the same as start(), except that the specified barrier is awaited immediately on execution.

        This method is designed to be used by clients who do not want to proceed until they know that log playback is scheduled.

        Parameters:
        barrier - The barrier on which to await.
